headline.print_headline: Breast-Fed Babies May Have a Leg Up In the Battle Against Childhood Obesity
headline.main: Breast-Fed Babies May Have a Leg Up in the Battle Against Childhood Obesity

docs.lead_paragraph: Exercise. Cut down on television. Eat more fruits and vegetables. Oh, and make sure your children are breast-fed.
docs.snippet: Exercise. Cut down on television. Eat more fruits and vegetables. Oh, and make sure your children are breast-fed.

docs.lead_paragraph: Is choosing bottle over breast like smoking during pregnancy? A controversial new public health effort suggests it is.
docs.snippet: Is choosing bottle over breast like smoking during pregnancy? A controversial new public health effort suggests it is.

docs.abstract: Increasing number of health organizations are warning against bottle feeding infants as health risk for baby and almost demanding that mothers breast feed their infants; Suzanne Haynes, Health and Human Services Department's Office on Women's Health senior scientific adviser says that not breast feeding is as risky to child as smoking during pregnancy; critics hold that many mothers cannot breast feed for variety of reasons and publishing harsh warnings against giving baby formula creates negative parenting situation with many mothers feeling guilty about not breast feedling; statistics on breast feeding and reported medical advantages for infant discussed; graphs; charts; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Warning: Public health officials have determined that not breast-feeding may be hazardous to your baby's health. There is no black-box label like that affixed to cans of infant formula or tucked into the corner of magazine advertisements, at least not yet. But that is the unambiguous message of a controversial government public health campaign encouraging new mothers to breast-feed for six months to protect their babies from colds, flu, ear infections, diarrhea and even obesity. In April, the World Health Organization, setting new international bench marks for children's growth, for the first time referred to breast-feeding as the biological norm.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Palestinian Factions Clash In an Eruption of Violence Hundreds of security personnel loyal to the Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas and his Fatah organization went on a rampage in Ramallah, firing bullets at the buildings of the Hamas-dominated Parliament and cabinet and setting them on fire. The attacks came after Hamas gunmen attacked the Gaza headquarters of the Fatah-dominated security forces with rockets and grenades. A1 Successor to Zarqawi Chosen An Islamic militant Web site said that a new leader had been chosen to replace Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the Jordanian terrorist killed last week, as the head of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia. The statement announced that a man named Abu Hamza al-Muhajir would replace Mr. Zarqawi. A14 President Bush gathered top aides at Camp David to determine the best way forward in Iraq during what the administration described as a critical juncture, following the death of Mr. Zarqawi and the final formation of a unity government. A10 Terror Suspects Charge Abuse Defense lawyers representing several of the men held on terrorism charges in an Ontario maximum security jail claim their clients have been beaten by guards, threatened by other inmates and held in isolation. The lawyers made the accusations as preliminary bail hearings were about to get under way for the 17 suspects arrested on June 3. A8 Iran Faulted for Withheld Data As Iran weighs how to respond to an international package of incentives intended to curb its nuclear activities, the chief of the International Atomic Energy Agency faulted Iran for failing to provide information crucial to understanding fully the nature and intent of its nuclear program. A6 Round 1 of Turkey Negotiation The European Union pushed forward with enlargement plans, conducting a first round of membership negotiations with Turkey and Croatia and signing a pre-membership agreement with Albania. A5 Kosovo Independence Closer Members of the United Nations Security Council appear to be leaning toward permitting Kosovo to go its own way. It seems increasingly likely that the province will be allowed to break away from Serbia formally and become an independent nation. A3 OBITUARIES C12-13 Kenneth R. Thomson A shy art collector who built Canada's largest fortune by transforming his father's trans-Atlantic newspaper business into one of the world's leading providers of electronic data and information, he was 82. C12 Gyorgy Ligeti The Central European composer whose music was among the most innovative of the last half of the 20th century, he was 83. C13 NATIONAL A16-21 Lethal Injection Challenges Allowed by Justices The Supreme Court opened the door for death-row inmates to challenge the way most states carry out executions by lethal injection. In its unanimous opinion, the court expressed no view on the constitutionality of lethal injection in general. A1 Islamic Teachings and Eldercare Uneasy discussions are taking place in Islamic enclaves nationwide as more families struggle with reconciling religious teachings on caring for elders with the modern realities of their chaotic American lives. A1 New Orleans Police Struggle Like the rest of New Orleans, the police force is still struggling to recover from the calamity of Hurricane Katrina, which knocked out its headquarters, overwhelmed its ability to maintain control and prompted desertions that tarnished the force's reputation. A1 A Rise in Violent Crime Violent crime increased in the United States for the first time in four years, up 2.5 percent in 2005 from the year before, with the largest increases in murder coming in medium-size cities and in the Midwest. A16 EDUCATION Lousiana Schools Get Aid Education Secretary Margaret Spellings announced that $24 million in federal aid had been awarded to Louisiana for the development of charter schools. A19 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Flight of Young Adults Causing Alarm Upstate Upstate New York is staggering from an accelerating exodus of young adults, new census results confirm. The migration is turning many communities grayer, threatening the long-term viability of already ailing cities and raising concerns about the state's future tax base. A1 New Roles for Keen Noses Dogs have long been partners in law enforcement's searches for narcotics, explosives and people (both dead and alive). But now their keen noses are being put to use in a wider variety of areas, like medicine, environmental protection and anti-piracy efforts. A1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 Encouraging Breast-Feeding A controversial government public health campaign is encouraging new mothers to breast-feed for six months to protect their babies from colds, flu, ear infections, diarrhea and even obesity. F1 Health & Fitness F5 SPORTSTUESDAY D1-6 Quarterback Injured in Wreck Ben Roethlisberger, the quarterback for the defending Super Bowl champion Pittsburgh Steelers, underwent surgery after sustaining multiple injuries in a motorcycle accident. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 U.A.W. Shifts Goals The United Automobile Workers convention opened in Las Vegas with leaders and members in a familiar fighting mood, but with a new battle plan aimed at protecting what they have rather than gaining new ground. C1 Reducing S.U.V. Threat A large number of sport utility vehicles and pickups that have been redesigned to reduce the threat they pose in collisions with smaller cars are now reaching the road. The changes are being made to prevent the S.U.V.'s and pickups from running over smaller vehicles in a crash. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Dirk Kempthorne arrives; life during wartime; someone has to find facts in Paris; a hole in the world. Columns: John Tierney, Nicholas D. Kristof. Crossword E10 TV Listings E11 Weather D7

headline.print_headline: In Diabetes, One More Burden for the Mentally Ill
headline.main: In Diabetes, One More Burden for the Mentally Ill

docs.lead_paragraph: Among the mentally ill, roughly one in five people appear to develop diabetes — about double the normal rate.
docs.snippet: Among the mentally ill, roughly one in five people appear to develop diabetes — about double the normal rate.
